comment.narrative:
1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and new jobs generation. Since 2007, the Employment Generation Programme helped create over 6,700 new start-ups. 36% of the newly created start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people Self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time in the country by UNDP
2. Since 2007. over 8,300 people have acquired entrepreneurship skills by attending trainings organized by UNDP supported projects
3. Micro and small enterprises (MSEs) limited in their ability to grow and thus hire more workers. In 2014, 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their business, creating additional 119 jobs. Since 2007, 306 MSEs have been supported and 446 new long-term jobs have been created.
4. The activity rate among young people aged 15-24 is extremely low, i.e. 30.6%, which is almost one third of that of persons aged 25-49 (80.1% in Q42014). 4 Youth Info Clubs at four technical faculties have been opened in the country in 2014.
5. 1,530 active users of PRV.mk; 6,500 application downloads; over 1,5 million web site visitors
6. In the period from 2012 to 2014, 220 unemployed people got 6 months short-term employment. In average, 70% of them are women and app. 40% are youth (aged up to 29 years);
7. N/A
8. Lack of supporting activities in the area of marketing and promotion to help the growth of micro and small companies
9. National partners need to enhance their capacity for providing e-services to registered unemployed persons
10. National partners need to improve their capacities for more active cooperation with the private sector and its direct involvement in local level labour market analyses
11. The Adult Education Centre is still not fully operational; institutions' responsibilities are not yet clearly defined, there is lack of coordination between different institutions; There are no procedures for the implementation of educational activiti

1. Provide technical assistance and advice in the process of designing the National Employment Strategy and follow-up programmes that accelerate employment and quality jobs creation for all; 900 self-employments/small businesses established and 60 additional created - 30% young people aged up to 29 - 38% women - 20 Roma - 120 companies established by persons with disability (2016)
2. Strengthening entrepreneurship and management capacities of 1,500 unemployed people in business planning and financial management; Additional 150 people with disabilities will receive training on business management. Barriers and risks and mentoring services will be provided to those that will establish a business during the first year (2016)
3. Up to 200 additional jobs supported in the previously established companies
4. 5 Youth Info Clubs supported in university centers throughout the country
5. Number of young people who use the mobile application PRV.MK
6. Support the establishment of local partnerships for provision of social services to vulnerable groups that will create part-time employment for 300 hard to employ job-seekers.
7. Training of 50 people to provide professional services to the elderly through the Community Works Programme

1. 942 people received coaching, training and small grants to start their own business. 35% of these new entrepreneurs are women and 29% are young people aged up to 29. Out of the 12 unemployed Roma who successfully completed the Self-Employment Programme, 9 started their new businesses.
2. 1,332 unemployed candidates underwent a training for strengthening their entrepreneurship and management skills and 1,256 obtained a certificate for successfully completing the training.
3. 72 micro and small companies received help to expand their businesses, creating another 111 jobs.
4. Contracts with 4 Youth Info Clubs were extended in 4 university centers. 1,732 students obtained information about job opportunities. The architectural design of the fifth Youth Info Club is developed and ready to be implemented in 2016 once a mutual agreement with the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering is reached.
5. PRV.mk is a smart application that brings the latest job openings directly to a mobile phone, including internships and volunteer positions. The app is functional for three mobile operating systems (Android, iOS and Windows Phone). Over 7,100 downloads and around 1,400 active users are registered by Play Store (Android). A new, advanced version of PRV.mk 2.0 has been introduced to all users, which will bring the latest news, tips and hints and other opportunities closer to young people.
6. The Community Works Programme supported 42 municipalities in tackling social exclusion on two fronts at once. Implemented by the Government, municipalities and UNDP, the Programme offered opportunities to 318 unemployed people to gain valuable skills while also providing social services to the most socially excluded groups in the country. Out of the 318 beneficiaries, 43% are young unemployed, aged up to 29. Over 10,000 socially excluded people in 42 municipalities have felt the benefits from the services provided through the Programme, with each municipality launching schemes of part-
120 self-employments/small businesses established by persons with disability and additional jobs created

117 self-employments/small businesses established by persons with disability and 24 additional jobs created. - 32 (27%) women entrepreneurs established businesses. - 85 (73%) men entrepreneurs established businesses, and - 20 (18%) young up to 29 y.

description.narrative: Number of specific assessments. Number of knowledge transfer tools, including tailor made training modules and number of trainees. Number of action plans addressing immediate needs of local stakeholders. Number of ICT interventions that enable open access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Number of social audits of local services and public expenditures performed. Number of partnerships between civil society organizations and public entities established. Number of Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms established. Number of services and policy products produced and delivered by the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms. Number of social entrepreneurship partnerships of Civil Society Organization and public and private entities. Number of local Commissions for Equal Opportunities that operate more frequently, effectively and efficiently. Number of recommendations for a local and regional policy action on climate change mitigation and adaptation.

comment.narrative: Limited local/planning region institutional capacities for inclusive governance and community based local and regional development. Limited funds for implementation of the Capacity Development Programme and Action Plan for improvement of the integrated local/planning region governance system of the Vardar Planning Region. Lack of comprehensive reporting on the financing of local services and limited access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Limited use of IT and social media for delivery of local services. Lack of regional and local funds to support operations and scaling up of the existing Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and establishment of new Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and social partnerships in the Vardar Planning region Lack of state incentives for establishment and functioning of Inter-Municipal Cooperation and social partnerships. The Ministry of Local Self-Government did not start updating and maintaining the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation knowledge management system and the E-evidence of established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and forms of international cooperation of the municipalities. Limited information on the needs of the vulnerable segments of the local communities related to their participation in local/regional governance processes. Local Commissions for Equal Opportunities do not operate frequently, effectively and efficiently. Lack of performance indicators to monitor and evaluate the progress in addressing the vulnerabilities as well as the quality of the most critical local services. Limited number of partnerships of the local/regional authorities with the private sector and civil society. Lack of social entrepreneurship initiatives and programmes. Limited bottom up generated evidence and efforts for down-streaming the programming of the local economic development and regional competitiveness as well as the agriculture and rural development in accordance with the respective chapters of the EU

A report analyzing municipal revenues and expenditures for 2014/2015 was prepared to collect data on the trends regarding the financing of municipalities and enable corrective actions.. Guidance and support for the implementation of one priority action from the 2014 – 2016 Programme of the Network for Inclusive Development of the Vardar Planning Region provided. Inter-municipal cooperation for provision of care to vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman and r addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities established, to enable economy of scale and delivery of new and innovative local services An elevator for people with disabilities purchased and installed in the seat of the municipality of Kavadarci and another elevator for children with disabilities purchased and installed in one elementary school in the municipality of Veles to demonstrate solutions for overcoming physical barriers and increasing the mobility of the people with disabilities Recreational equipment for people with disabilities purchased and installed in one recreational site in each of the Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman municipalities to create better conditions for recreation of people with disabilities.

The Reports analyzing municipal revenues and expenditures for 2014/ and the first half of 2015 were prepared. Organization of the third “Partners Day” in the Vardar Planning region was supported – the event will be held in the forst quarter of 2016 Inter-municipal cooperation for provision of care to vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman and for addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities was established. Elevator for pupils with disabilities was purchased and installed in one primary school in Veles. In addition a lavatory in the school was refurbished. In the frame of the campaign to raise public awareness about people with special needs and disabilities a one-day visit to the St. Georgia monastery in Negotino was organized for more than 70 people with special needs and disabilities of all ages by the NGO - Association of people with cerebral paralyses – Veles. Equipment for exercise of persons with special needs and disabilities were purchased and installed in Veles Youth Park and Kavadarci Park. Construction of gazebos for people with disabilities and landscaping of the area around them in municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Rosoman, Cashka and Gradsko was completed.

1.1 Preparation of Report with analyses of the municipal revenues and expenditures in 2015 and the first half of 2016 2.1 Provision of guidance and support for implementation of the 2014 – 2015 Programme for the Network for Inclusive Development of the Vardar Planning Region 2.2 Organization of the third Partners day of the Vardar planning Region and support of the cooperation between the Vardar planning region and the Region ALSACE of France in the field of wine production and exchange of good practices 2.3 Support of the inter – municipal cooperation for provision of care of vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Caska and Rosoman and for addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities

Contribution to the improvement of the Prespa Lake’s Ecological State and its Resilience
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Prespa region

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

At least 8% reduction of nutrient loads (and other substances) to the lake as a result of the gradual increase of project supported measures % of hectares under Good Agricultural Practices and/or agro-ecological measures $ of area under nature-based systems (wetlands, river corridors, buffers) Quantity of collected pesticide packaging and biodegradable waste Functional Watershed Management Committee as a formal cross-sectoral participatory mechanism for integrated watershed management # of knowledge products (manuals, guidance documents, lessons learnt booklets, fact sheets and articles)

comment.narrative: High proportion of the delineated water bodies in the Prespa Lake watershed doesn’t meet the requirement of having ‘good’ ecological status according to the existing regulations Important natural landscape elements (ecotones) are being destroyed over the past decades as a result of development pressures The current nutrient loads of anthropogenic origin (500 t/year) exceed the levels the lake ecosystem can absorb without further degrading Unsustainable farming practices, especially overuse of pesticides, fertilizers and irrigation water No sufficient monitoring and management capacities exist at present The current organizational structure and capacity of Municipality of Resen and other responsible organizations / institutions doesn’t meet the needs of an integrated watershed management system Low level of awareness about nature protection and sustainable use of natural resources

Completion of Phase 2 of the Eutrophication study: Model development and application of alternative management scenarios Implementation of the 2 cycle of agro-ecological farming practices measures in Prespa and inclusion of at least 40 new farmers in the grant scheme (at least 5 of them female). Final decision on the scope of wetland restoration reached and start of implementation of the wetland restoration alternative Implementation of Priority erosion control measures implemented on an area of at least 40 ha of forest land Implementation of at least 10 community driven small-scale infrastructure projects Regular monitoring reports generated by the Lake Monitoring Station

The Eutrophication study: Model development and application of alternative management scenarios completed Implementation of the 2 cycle of agro-ecological farming practices measures in Prespa successfully completed with inclusion of total 77 farmers in two cycles, out of which 10 female farmers Alternative solutions for implementation of the wetland restoration elaborated and decision on the final solution of wetland restoration reached Priority erosion control measures implemented on an area of 40 ha of forest land 10 community driven small-scale infrastructure projects (reconstruction of water supply and sewage collection systems, small eco-parks in two villages, etc) implemented in the municipality of Resen The Lake Monitoring Station in Stenje fully operational and regularly generates monitoring reports for the Prespa Lake

Finalization of the eutrophication model and user training on model application; User training on model application (Output 1.1)
Locally implemented forest regeneration activities in priority erosion areas with plant material produced at project-backed the forest nursery (Output 1.2)
Completion of all three cycles of the grants programme to support agro-ecological farming practices; Finalization of the feasibility study on irrigation options for the Prespa Lake Basin (Output 1.3)
Launching wetland restoration activities (Output 1.4)
Continuation of operation of the composting plant in Resen (Output 1.5)
Completion of all initiated small-scale environmental/water infrastructure projects (Output 1.7)
Completion of the pilot monitoring programme (by the Hydrobiological Institute) and continuation of regular monitoring programme by the Lake Monitoring Station (Output 2.1)
Delivery of upgraded/advanced capacity development programme for the representatives of the new Sector on Environment (Output 2.2)
Support exchanges and partnering with the existing relevant professional networks and lake regions (Output 2.3)

1. The eutrophication modeling has been completed, including the advanced simulations of possible changes to watershed phosphorus loading taking into consideration projected future climate conditions. Coupled with the ongoing training programme for municipal personnel, these efforts will enable the future use of the model as a significant decision-support system informing future strategies, and development plans for the watershed. 2. Following the initial forest regeneration activities implemented earlier in 2015, the Public Forest Enterprise continued with similar action on an additional area of approximately 30 hectares of eroded land (75 hectares of eroded land were reforested in total in 2015 with over 400,000 trees). The planting material produced at the project-supported native forest nursery is used for this purpose. This has positive economic effects for the Public Forest Enterprise that is now able to save nearly 20,000 USD per year. 3. Thanks to the earlier training and on-demand technical assistance, the 77 selected grantees managed to significantly improve farming practices in their pilot orchards in a combined area of approximately 76 hectares. The positive effects of the use of the new practices may be illustrated by the following examples: a) the use of irrigation water on the pilot orchards is by 60% lower compared to earlier irrigation practices; b) there is 40-50% reduction in the application of phosphorus and nitrogen based fertilizers as a result of the more balanced nutrition. As a result, about 65 tons of annual phosphorus and 5 tons of annual nitrogen loading has been kept out of water bodies thanks to modern farming practices implemented at the pilot apple orchards alone. Municipal estimates say that the modern farming practices have been extended to an additional area of approximately 1,000 hectares of apple orchards. 4. Following the completion of the necessary preparatory activities (e.g., restoration design and review stage, communicatio

• Full transition toward municipal implementation modality is achieved following the complete staffing of the Sector on Environment, sustainability instruments are operational and UNDP-backed implementation phases-out • Wetland restoration activities in the Ezerani Nature Park are completed • Irrigation scheduling system is introduced based on agro-meteorological monitoring data and model development

description.narrative: 1) The staff of the Energy Efficiency Department within the Municipality of Karposh is trained in municipal energy management and is regularly using the energy management system. An effective system for remote sensing is in place and is in regular use. The ExCITE software is regularly used and updated. 2) A number of cost-effective energy efficiency measures are implemented in the selected buildings (school and kindergarten). The early measurement and verification show decrease in energy use and costs. 3) Upgrades of ExCITE software has been developed pursuing the legal requirements and in a consultation process with the municipalities. The municipalities are regularly using the upgraded version of the software in their monitoring and management of energy. 4) At least two additional municipalities entered in cost-sharing agreement with UNDP for implementation of efficiency measures and/ or introduction of systematic energy management practices.

comment.narrative: 1) The Municipality of Karposh is a pioneer vis-à-vis the establishment of a system and organizational structure for municipal energy monitoring and management. The Municipality of Karposh has established and staffed a separate Energy Efficiency Department, and expressed its commitment to streamline the energy management by developing a remote sensing system. 2) The Municipality of Karposh expressed its commitment to finance and implement energy efficiency measures in two public buildings (a school and a kindergarten) on a cost-sharing arrangement with UNDP. 3) The ExCITE software has been developed and is in use. The amendments to the Energy Law are expected to make the use and regular update of ExCITE mandatory for all municipalities. The municipalities have expressed their interest in upgrading the software which would allow them an effective monitoring and management of energy use. 4) A number of municipalities have expressed strong interest to implement energy efficiency measures and/ or introduce energy management systems on a cost-sharing arrangement with UNDP.
New partnership with local governments established or expanded and energy efficiency measures implemented in at least two public buildings (schools and/or kindergartens)

Energy efficiency measures were implemented in one kindergarten in the municipality of Kisela Voda, and the high School in the City of Skopje, and new alternative source of heating was ensured for one school in the municipality of Karposh. All activities were implemented on a cost-sharing basis between UNDP and the municipalities, and majority of the funds were provided by the municipality while UNDP was mostly providing advice and technical support.
Partnership with the local government of Kisela Voda expanded and energy efficiency measures implemented in at least one public building (school and/or kindergarten).

The renovation of the sport hall of the public school “Nevena Georgieva Dunja” in the municipality of Kisela Voda completed by implementation of energy efficiency measures thus creating conditions for reduction of energy bills for the school and better working conditions for the pupils. All activities were implemented on a cost-sharing basis between UNDP and the Municipality of Kisela Voda, and majority of the funds were provided by the municipality while UNDP was mostly providing advice and technical support.
The project has no activities in 2017. Pending formal completion payment of outstanding expenses.

description.narrative: Comprehensive citizens’ satisfaction survey designed and implemented. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the survey results. Crosscutting analyses prepared and decentralization strategic framework adjusted. A partnership programme designed and implemented. Local e-services study prepared. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the results. Local e-services road-map prepared. In-depth analysis of the existing Inter –Municipal Cooperation practices and the current Inter –Municipal Cooperation policies presented to the Government. Best Inter –Municipal Cooperation practice award established and at least two Inter –Municipal Cooperation arrangements supported. Assessment report on the possibility to establish a Unit for Support of Private Enterprises within the Centers for Regional Development, prepared. New Decentralization Programme for the period 2015 – 2020, prepared.

comment.narrative: No updated data and analyses of citizens’ perceptions on the quality of local services, resulting in policies and actions that do not reflect citizens’ priority needs. Lack of innovative partnership programme to address service delivery. No updated and sufficient data and analyses of existing local e-services and related needs and opportunities. Inter –Municipal Cooperation evidence system established. Mid-term decentralization policy review completed. Lack of state financial support for Inter –Municipal Cooperation, resulting in insufficient utilization of this tool for alternative service delivery. Centers for development of the planning regions face serious sustainability issues due to an inappropriate financing system. The existing decentralization programme expires in 2014, which creates a risk for the country to remain without a very important policy for the development of its local self-government system.

The Local e-Services Study finalized and endorsed by the Government to create a basis for the formulation of a new policy for modernization of municipal services The inclusive development networks of the Vardar Pelagonia and Northeast planning regions supported to implement priority actions derived from their Programmes and Action Plans. Technical support provided to the State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission for amending the Law on Inter-Municipal Cooperation and the related policy. The Centers for development of the five planning regions (Skopje, Polog, East, Southwest and Southeast Regions) supported in preparation of Programmes, Action Plans and Communication Strategies of the newly established Business Centers for Support of Small and Medium Enterprises . Implementation of activities for increasing regional competitiveness supported. Transfer of international best practices on distribution of state aid for private sector research and development at regional level and attraction of foreign investments enabled through study trip to the Czech Republic and three workshops with Czech experts in the country. Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 – 2020 finalized and endorsed by the Government and broadly disseminated. 2015 – 2017 Action Plan of the Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 – 2020 and Monitoring Methodology prepared and endorsed by the Government. Third Annual Conference on Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization, organized with the aim to gather all relevant stakeholders in taking stock of the implementation of the decentralization policy in 2015 and formulating joint recommendations and prioritizing actions for 2016. Potentials for development of forms of rural tourism in the four (4) least developed planning regions in the country (Northeast, Vardar, Southwest and Polog) mapped and rural tourism registers prepared, thus creating basis for more accurate preparation

The final Draft of an Integrated Study on Local e-Services was discussed and endorsed by the Government Committee on e-Services. Integrated Regional Development Network (IRDN) was formed in the Pelagonia Planning Region, and the Platform for Regional Rural Action (PRRA) was established in the Northeast Planning Region. Both Networks prepared Programmes of Work and respective Action Plans and started with the implementation of priority activities. Premises where both Networks operate were refurbished. The Vardar Region Inclusive Network continued with implementation of the 2013 – 2015 Programme of work. Center for Development of Pelagonija Planning Region held 2 promotional events for increasing capacities of the business sector (one workshop on agricultural business and the other workshop on utilization of domestic and foreign financial instruments, organized with the Regional Chamber of Commerce). Centre for Development of Vardar Planning Region held the event for promotion of the three products: the Guide for investors, the Map/Collection of the Industrial Zones and the web portal. The economic operator presented the products before the mayors, as well as representatives of business and civil sector. Based on a pre-prepared analysis of existing practices and current Inter-Municipal Cooperation (IMC), a Draft Law amending the Law on IMC was prepared. The State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission was assisted in preparation of the 2015 IMC Status Report. The brochure Inter-Municipal Cooperation in the Republic of Macedonia was published.
Programs for Private Sector Support, including an Action Plan and Communication Plan for Program Implementation were prepared by the Business Centers established for support and advisory services to SMEs in Skopje, Polog, East, Southeast and Southwest Planning Regions. In all 5 Centers, altogether 28 informational events were organized and attended by a total of 1053 participants (586 men and 467 women), most of whom were repr

Implementation of the Management Plan for Strumica River Basin
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The region of Strumica Watershed - 6 municipalities in South-East planning region

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: • Launching the development of flood hazard and flood risk maps for the Strumica River Basin • Launching the programme to improve pollution prevention and control through strengthening permitting and enforcement capacities • Start of process for identification of most feasible basin-scale wastewater management options • Launching of a technical assistance framework for introduction of agro-ecological farming practices for priority crops in the Basin • Upgrade of the water quality monitoring database for the key water bodies in the Basin

1. Setting grounds for phased industrial pollution reduction through strengthening administrative capacities for environmental permitting and raising community awareness 2. Defining long-term basin-scale wastewater management strategy 3. Initiation of a multi-year transformative programme for adopting agro-ecological farming practices 4. Developing planning base for reducing flood risks in the Strumica River Basin to acceptable levels 5. Piloting comprehensive basin-scale water monitoring programme aligned with the principles of the EU Water Framework Directive

1. Thanks to the project’s capacity development programme, the responsible municipal personnel and the Basin’s major industrial operators have improved their skills and knowledge on integrated pollution prevention and control. A total of 16 nominated environmental permitting officials from all six Basin municipalities have undergone a comprehensive on-the-job training on integrated pollution prevention and control. Also number of industry operators and environmental NGOs took part in the programme that has been co-designed in a way to overcome some of the key barriers to introducing a more effective environmental permitting system and consequently phased pollution reduction in the Basin.
2. Based on the feasibility assessment of multiple options and approaches in terms of aggregation of communities in agglomerations, wastewater treatment technologies and financial consequences, local governments of the Basin’s municipalities have engaged in a process of adopting a long-term wastewater management strategy and identifying investment priorities. These process identified and conceptualized affordable wastewater management options for about 65,000 people living in the rural communities of the Basin. This has provided the basis for long-term actions in overcoming wastewater management-related issues in the Basin that are among the key sources of pressures to water bodies.
3. A comprehensive programme has been launched to stimulate transformation of farming practices in the Basin into more contemporary approaches of agro-ecological farming and precision agriculture. The programme focuses on demonstrating more sustainable farming of selected fruits (apples, peaches and plums) and vegetables (tomatoes and peppers). The successfully completed training programme delivered to selected farmers was followed up by the selection of thirty farmer grantees who will be supported to implement new scalable and replicable farming practices on thirty pilot farms across the Basin.

• Capacity development assistance for Basin’s municipalities, community awareness activities and spatial analysis of industrial pollution are completed as part of the activities for operationalizing integrated pollution prevention and control system at basin-scale • Complete technical documentation for wastewater management systems for at least six communities is completed and decentralized wastewater treatment system is demonstrated in at least one rural community in the Strumica River Basin • The first grants cycle for farmers is completed and a second cycle is launched to help transform farming toward more sustainable practices • Strategic partnership with one larger agricultural producer is established and modern farming practices are applied on pilot plots • Dam/reservoir operating regimes are optimized for reducing flood risk based on decision-support models aligned with the Flood Risk Management Plan • The basin-scale water monitoring programme is continued and upgraded • Basin-scale floods early warning system is piloted

description.narrative: Urban resilience action plan and climate change strategy for the City of Skopje in place. Gender considerations incorporated in the urban disaster and climate resilience action plans. # of targeted capacity strengthening programmes implemented. # of replications and scaling up of the existing mobile disaster risk reduction and climate change application # of ICT solutions for information sharing/public awareness raising on urban resilience, including solutions that take into consideration the needs of vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

comment.narrative: Lack of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience action plans in the country. Insufficient technical knowledge and expertise for preparation of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience plans. Ad-hoc integration of disaster and climate change issues into national policies and strategies. Low public awareness on urban resilience on disaster and climate risks. Low level of cooperation and information sharing between different level of stakeholders and organizations dealing with disastwer risk reduction; Poor integration of ICT led disaster risk reduction solutions for vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

Draft Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plans for the City of Skopje developed with participation of men and women. Two targeted capacity strengthening programme for the key stakeholders implemented Inventory of Greenhouse gasses for City of Skopje as per the 2006 IPCC guidelines for two years (2008 and 2012) developed - database and narrative report. Stakeholder map with indicated key stakeholders and information flows developed. 10 local thematic groups for identification of priority vulnerable sectors established as a consultative mechanism for development of a Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje. Draft Climate Change Strategy for City of Skopje developed. Rapid Assessment of the current situation and needs for ICT for Urban Resilience conducted. Mobile DRR applications replication/scaling up initiated in the participating countries.

Inventory of Greenhouse gasses for City of Skopje as per the 2006 IPCC guidelines for two years (2008 and 2012) and mitigation narrative report developed. 15 foresight based stakeholder workshops to identify the vulnerable sectors and priorities for preparation of the strategy carried, 290 persons participated at the workshops ranging from high schools, municipal representatives, city administration and representatives from national institutions on local level. The key priorities and vulnerable sectors for development of the Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje and the action plan were identified. Rapid Assessment of the current situation and needs for ICT for Urban Resilience conducted.Analysis and recommendations for an integrated spatial platform for urban resilience were done based on the analysis of the existing and planned geo and spatial service and information databases in City of Skopje, and the participating institutions. The system for urban resilience of City of Skopje shall be with SOA (Service Oriented Architecture) and shall be divided in two parts: WEB GIS platform for urban resilience in City of Skopje and spatial data aggregator hosted in Crisis Management Centre. In MKD a mobile application for safe evacuation with using of QR codes was developed and has “Disaster Buddy” module that send the location and text to three contacts in case of crisis or disasters

1. Draft version of the Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plan for the City of Skopje developed
2. First ever Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje – Resilient Skopje finalized
3. Skopje Green Cadastre framework established
4. Flood model system for the City of Skopje prepared
5. Climate change and urban resilience challenge launched.
6. Draft version of the National Risk and Hazard Assessment updated with recent disastrous events including the Skopje flooding form August 2016.

- Draft version of the Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plan of the City of Skopje was developed through participation of the representatives of the City of Skopje and municipalities on the territory of the city. It lays ground for strengthening the capacities of the local government to design and implement integrated disaster and climate risk reduction plans and programmes.
- First ever Skopje Green Cadastre framework established for better management with the public greenery enhancing the urban resilience of the city. In total 650 ha of urban greenery were geodetically surveyed, mobile app for trees inventorization developed and foundations of GIS platforms for improved management of the public greenery established, including mobile solution for citizens crowdsourcing of data on trees and shrubs.
- The citizens of Skopje are better adapted to climate changes as a result of development of the Climate Change Strategy – Resilient Skopje. The strategy includes action plan with defined time framework for implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures and actions.
- Floods hazards and risks for the City of Skopje identified and modelled for better prevention and response including the preliminary estimation of damages and losses. This type of GIS modelling supports the flood risk assessment process through improved preparation of scenarios and plans for floods on the territory of the City of Skopje.
- In partnership with USAID, Swedish Embassy, the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, MilieKontakt Macedonia, the Social Innovation Hub and FINKI, the “It Depends on You” challenge was organized for second year in row. The challenge engaged citizens and broader public to propose solutions for climate change adaptation and increasing the urban resilience. The winning solution was ReBoot – smart recycling. In addition, several other ideas were awarded and possible support: Treebook – crowdsourcing of trees and better public greenery management and Air p

- Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plan for the City of Skopje developed - One simulation exercise for testing the Plan implemented - Registry of underground wells on the territory of GUP of the City of Skopje established - External Plan of operators for technological hazards prepared - Smart City Concept and Sustainability chapter from the Strategy developed - Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje adopted and published - Priority measures for CC adaptation and mitigation as identified in the Resilient Skopje Strategy implemented - Skopje Green Cadaster operationally established

comment.narrative:
42.8 % of total damages and losses occurred in the infrastructure sector due to the floods that occured in 2015 . Increased risk and vulnerability of transport infrastructure through instability of sloping terrain that may cause further landslides, the occurrence of aftershocks following an earthquake, and possible occurrence of further intensive rainfall and flooding
Limited knowledge about the contemporary approaches for recovery of infrastructure in accordance with the ‘build back better’ principles. The current design approaches often do not take the importance of enhancing resilience of the infrastructure into consideration
Sign of the Project Document with the EU Delegation and initiate activities for the start up of the project
The Project Document with the EU Delegation signed on 20 November and activities to start up da project initiated.

1. Almost 40,000 people from five (out of eight selected) flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure 2. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll

1. As a response to the widespread 2015-floods that occurred in country’s east, southeast and Pelagonija regions, UNDP launched all eight transport infrastructure reconstruction projects that are part of the EU Flood Recovery Programme. Five out of eight projects have been fully or nearly completed producing considerable benefits for a population of almost 40,000 people. The transport infrastructure restored in line with the ‘build back better’ principles helps restore connectivity, reduces travel time and increases resilience to future floods of communities in the following five municipalities: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (over 7,000 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road of 6.5 km). The size of positively affected population is expected to double once the three other ongoing projects are completed.
2. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raising programme targeting key communities and beneficiaries. Similar survey at the end of the programme will measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.

• Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented as part of the second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the transport infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

description.narrative:
% of improved flood protection of the City of Tetovo as a result of the reconstructed check-dams on Pena River.
Quantity of waste material removed and % of improved discharge capacity as a result from waste clean-up campaigns
At least 5 new monitoring stations operational in the Polog region
Protocols for early warning and public alert system for floods

comment.narrative: The check-dams on the Pena River are damaged to different degrees undermining the protection of Tetovo against future floods. No proper flood mitigation infrastructure for the village of Sipkovica exists Large quantities of waste illegally deposited above the village of Sipkovica and high risk of harmful debris flow that might be activated by future flash flood events. No flash-flood early-warning and public alert system for Polog is in place at the moment The system of meteorological and hydrological stations operates at very limited levels, insufficient for an appropriate flood-preparedness and response

1. The people and important critical assets of the City of Tetovo are better protected against future flash floods as a result of the reconstruction of three (out of six) check-dams
2. About 3,000 m3 of waste material were removed from historical dumpsites in the Polog region, reducing environmental pressures and human health risks in densely populated areas
3. Setting grounds for introduction of a flash-flood early warning and public alert system

1. Following the devastating 2015-flash floods in the Polog Region that caused a damage of 21.5 EUR and killed six people, UNDP supported the reconstruction of three damaged check-dams on the Pena River in the City of Tetovo – region’s administrative center counting a population of over 50,000 people. The reconstructed check-dams greatly improve the safety of communities and critical infrastructure along region’s largest and most powerful torrential stream – the Pena River. Additional options for upgrading the protection to optimal levels are also being analyzed. The reconstruction design was developed in a way to improve structural stability of the check-dams system and their overall performance.
2. Important historical dumpsites were cleaned from a few priority sites in the Polog Region, including the City of Tetovo’s centrally-positioned non-compliant temporary dumpsite. By this clean-up campaign, considerable reduction in the environmental pressures and human health risks has been achieved, especially having in mind that the City of Tetovo is among the areas facing most serious waste-management related consequences in the entire country.
3. The previous flood risk modeling efforts for the Polog region proposed a network of hydrological and meteorological monitoring stations that are actually present the key elements of the flash-flood early warning and public alert system. The monitoring stations have been provided and the preparatory construction works have been completed that will allow for their installation in the course of the next year.

• Capacity development assistance for Basin’s municipalities, community awareness activities and spatial analysis of industrial pollution are completed as part of the activities for operationalizing integrated pollution prevention and control system at basin-scale • Complete technical documentation for wastewater management systems for at least six communities is completed and decentralized wastewater treatment system is demonstrated in at least one rural community in the Strumica River Basin • The first grants cycle for farmers is completed and a second cycle is launched to help transform farming toward more sustainable practices • Strategic partnership with one larger agricultural producer is established and modern farming practices are applied on pilot plots • Dam/reservoir operating regimes are optimized for reducing flood risk based on decision-support models aligned with the Flood Risk Management Plan • The basin-scale water monitoring programme is continued and upgraded • Basin-scale floods early warning system is piloted

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Output 1: • Total length of cleaned/restored river regulations and drainage network (improved discharge capacity): a. Crna Reka: 57 km of main regulated riverbed 106 km secondary channel network and drainage canals (tributaries) 600 m restored embankments on Crna Reka b. Strumica: 24 km of main regulated riverbed • Minimum original (design) flood conveyance capacity is achieved in restored river sections/drainage canals • Minimum four reconstructed dams / reservoirs (Mavrovica, Drenska Reka, Lipa and Slatina dams) • Reduced frequency in overflowing of recovered dams (as a result of improved operating regimes)
Output 2: • Optimization models for minimum four (4) dams/reservoirs • Guidance document for incorporating the ‘build back better’ principle in the reconstruction of water infrastructure projects • # of knowledge products and public awareness material

comment.narrative:
Output 1 26 percent of the drainage systems, 17 percent of the irrigation systems and 3 percent of the dams were damaged in 32 municipalities. The dams of Mavrovica, Slatina, Drenska and Lipa suffered major damage during the early 2015 floods. As a result their flood control and other purposes are undermined The drainage network and regulated riverbeds in the Crna Reka and Strumica River Basins are damaged and poorly maintained. As a result they perform their flood mitigation function only in a very limited fashion.
Output 2 The operating regimes of existing flood control structures (dams/reservoirs) do not maximize their flood mitigation potential. There is limited understanding of the ‘building back better’ approach and enhanced resilience objectives in reconstruction projects at national level.

1. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Strumica River Basin are reduced by 10% compared to their current baseline levels. 2. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Pelagonija region are reduced by 35% compared to their current baseline levels. 3. Recovery efforts are initiated in two out of four selected priority dams in flood-sensitive regions in the country 4. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll.

1. The clean-up of almost 30 km of river canals network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – improves the resilience of the region against future flood events. The discharge capacity of canals has been increased by ~50% that would prevent average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. To achieve higher protection, recovery of damaged parts of flood protection embankments still remains to be performed. 2. Almost 45 km of damaged and largely neglected river canals/flood control network in the Pelagonija region has been cleaned-up and rehabilitated to improve protection of agricultural and urbanized land. Over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years, as a result of the improved discharge capacity of the rehabilitated priority river sections. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure. 3. The recovery of two out of four selected dams damaged by the floods in 2015 has been initiated in line with the ‘build back better’ principles. Once completed the rehabilitation works will improve operation of Mavrovica and Lipa dams in satisfying various uses (e.g., irrigation and flood control) in two municipalities severely affected by the 2015-floods with total population of nearly 40,000 people (Mavrovica dam in Sveti Nikole and Lipa dam in Negotino). 4. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raisi

• River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in both Strumica River Basin and Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of 10% and 35% respectively • Recovery efforts are initiated on all four selected priority dams and two of them are fully recovered • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

description.narrative: Social Innovation Labs institutionalized in the City of Skopje work, providing a new generation of services and servicing at least two departments within the municipality

comment.narrative: Regional Social Innovation Lab in Skopje is now serving UNDP projects and only indirectly serving national counterparts.

- City of Skopje management buy-in of the model and commitment ensured - Innovation framework for the City of Skopje developed - Capacity building programme prepared - The concept (business strategy) for the City of Skopje Innovation Lab incl service lines and scope of work developed - Physical space for the Lab dedicated and equipped - 2 policy areas selected and 4 pilots tested

The analysis undertaken in preparation for the establishment of the City of Skopje Innovation Lab show that 86% of the respondents perceive City of Skopje as not open to their’ ideas, recommendations and proposals for better design and delivery of public services or project. And almost the same percentage think that City of Skopje lack transparency in the process of decision making. 70 % of the respondents are partly satisfied or not satisfied with the quality of the services provided. All 15 departments within the City of Skopje find the lack of supportive culture and an enhanced innovative and learning environment as a reason for low employee’ motivation for innovation. This is strong enough reason that proves the need of for establishment of the Lab, for which all preparations are completed and the official launch of the Lab scheduled for January 2017. In 2016: • Innovation framework for the city of Skopje, that defines an innovation process that can be used for successful innovation development is developed • The Concept for the Innovation Lab, as space where employees together with citizens can explore and experiment innovations is designed and Action plan for 2017 with activities, proposed time for realization and stakeholders included as a response to the identified problems is prepared • Capacity building plan for the employees of the City of Skopje for 2017/18 with defined scope, goal and user segment, in order to empower the employees with knowledge and tools to innovate is drafted In addition, 2 pilot policy areas (environmental protection and sustainable transport) were identified and 5 prototypes (testing crowdsourcing, design challenges and hackathon, human-centered design, data innovation (remote-sensing – drones for improved data collection) were run to test the concept and collect lessons learn to incorporate into the framework and determine the focus of the Lab. title.narrative: Response to Flash Floods in Skopje and Tetovo

description.narrative: The Post-Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA) that UNDP is undertaking together with the EU and the World Bank to assess the impact of the flash floods in Skopje is expected to identify further urgent priorities for flood preventing.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
# of sectors identified # of participants in PDNA process # of reports # of counterparts supported # of coordination meetings held # of reports produced

comment.narrative:
1. Following the devastating August 2016 flash floods that caused significant damage and killed 23 people, UNDP supported the PDNA work of national partners, in coordination with the World Bank and EU. Participatory approach was ensured through the central coordination of the Secretariat of European Affairs and key work of the seven sector groups.
2. Within the framework of the PDNA works, the damage, recovery and risk-reduction needs in seven sectors were assessed and incorporated in the final draft of the PDNA Report.
3. Technical support was provided to the Government and the cities administrations in formulating of the early recovery frameworks and action plans.
- PDNA published - Improved post-disaster capacity based on expert advice.

description.narrative: Deriving Data to Design Better Services for Persons with Disabilities
Deriving Data to Design Better Services for Persons with Disabilities
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: The intended beneficiaries of this project are at the level of whole country, however the activities are focused in three regions - Skopje, Strumica and Pelagonija.

description.narrative: Health - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: - Two field surveys on the needs of persons with disabilities and quality of life and services of persons with disabilitiesplaced in foster families carried out; - First training session to 15 professionals carried out;

Two surveys have been carried out, one focused on biological and the other on foster families, to understand better the capabilities as well as the barriers for their integration at the labour market. 590 families with members that have disabilities and 91 foster families have successfully filled in our survey, by the end of Dec '16. Results will be available by the end of Feb '17. Through mapathon initiative UNDP piloted mapping of physical barriers in the city of Negotino. The intervention will continue to cover app 30 cities in the country during the first Q of this year. Work oriented rehabilitation training has been initiated to prepare professionals to gain the knowledge on how to assess people abilities and increase their capabilities for higher engagement in the labor market and in the society. Additionally, one-day workshop was organized for professionals working in 3 institutions in the country, to discuss the barriers towards deinstitutionalization process in the country.
